{"id_": "08c5ef2b-a06c-49a0-9a8b-7ce64e3f39cd", "embedding": null, "metadata": {}, "excluded_embed_metadata_keys": [], "excluded_llm_metadata_keys": [], "relationships": {"1": {"node_id": "a8133274-08a7-4cea-8b20-98c666a8ac97", "node_type": "4", "metadata": {}, "hash": "c9a102ee6aadb49c6fcb6e71a157b0335ce70961fb42a31f804942361bfc510c", "class_name": "RelatedNodeInfo"}, "3": {"node_id": "647c153a-1ffa-43ea-8834-58b6a6e057b1", "node_type": "1", "metadata": {"Header_1": "What is Wollastonite?"}, "hash": "43887df33675492f0ea1e743cc24e8fd75e8c4cd3e76f4abbec5935e3d82b6d0", "class_name": "RelatedNodeInfo"}}, "text": "#Calcium_additive #raise_ph #Wollastonite #Silicon_additive #buffer_pH #Calcium
Growers  turn to Wollastonite for:
- Its **liming** capability.  Wollastonite's dissolution rate is slower than agricultural lime, offering a buffering effect against rapid pH changes. This makes Wollastonite beneficial in areas with fluctuating acidity levels.
- Adding **Silicon**.
- Adding **Calcium**.
Wollastonite's pH buffering effect and Silicon content contribute to pest control and powdery mildew suppression, although the exact mechanisms are not fully understood.", "mimetype": "text/plain", "start_char_idx": 0, "end_char_idx": 555, "text_template": "{metadata_str}

{content}", "metadata_template": "{key}: {value}", "metadata_seperator": "
", "class_name": "TextNode"}

{"id_": "ca4ca1b9-548e-4b75-82c7-9474181d380c", "embedding": null, "metadata": {"Header_1": "What is Wollastonite?", "Header_2": "Industrial Applications of Wollastonite"}, "excluded_embed_metadata_keys": [], "excluded_llm_metadata_keys": [], "relationships": {"1": {"node_id": "a8133274-08a7-4cea-8b20-98c666a8ac97", "node_type": "4", "metadata": {}, "hash": "c9a102ee6aadb49c6fcb6e71a157b0335ce70961fb42a31f804942361bfc510c", "class_name": "RelatedNodeInfo"}, "2": {"node_id": "b3b9b371-5141-4067-959a-66cc8c572213", "node_type": "1", "metadata": {"Header_1": "What is Wollastonite?", "Header_2": "Sources"}, "hash": "28efa3a08bd580ef65c66f784ce417656623807755bad3845543349871c0861e", "class_name": "RelatedNodeInfo"}, "3": {"node_id": "a688181c-0b74-4584-b94d-003ddc8c4597", "node_type": "1", "metadata": {"Header_1": "What is Wollastonite?", "Header_2": " How Wollastonite Provides Plants with Ca and Si"}, "hash": "f230e191b073dd3b6f625c9ac9f5586c5381c8ee0b4d1ed3faf63c9bdb380501", "class_name": "RelatedNodeInfo"}}, "text": "Industrial Applications of Wollastonite

|Industry|Application|
|---|---|
|Ceramics|Smoother and more durable ceramics, reinforcement agent|
|Plastics and Rubber|Cost-effective strengthening agent|
|Paints and Coatings|Reinforcement, improved durability and impact resistance|
|Construction|Improved strength and durability of building materials, safe alternative to asbestos|", "mimetype": "text/plain", "start_char_idx": 1186, "end_char_idx": 1562, "text_template": "{metadata_str}

{content}", "metadata_template": "{key}: {value}", "metadata_seperator": "
", "class_name": "TextNode"}

Header_2: How Wollastonite Provides Plants with Ca and Si
How Wollastonite Provides Plants with Ca and Si
_node_content:
{"id_": "057af084-29d5-4a5d-a507-5faa5b4ac162", "embedding": null, "metadata": {"Header_1": "What is Wollastonite?", "Header_2": " How Wollastonite Provides Plants with Ca and Si", "Header_3": "Calcium"}, "excluded_embed_metadata_keys": [], "excluded_llm_metadata_keys": [], "relationships": {"1": {"node_id": "a8133274-08a7-4cea-8b20-98c666a8ac97", "node_type": "4", "metadata": {}, "hash": "c9a102ee6aadb49c6fcb6e71a157b0335ce70961fb42a31f804942361bfc510c", "class_name": "RelatedNodeInfo"}, "2": {"node_id": "a688181c-0b74-4584-b94d-003ddc8c4597", "node_type": "1", "metadata": {"Header_1": "What is Wollastonite?", "Header_2": " How Wollastonite Provides Plants with Ca and Si"}, "hash": "f230e191b073dd3b6f625c9ac9f5586c5381c8ee0b4d1ed3faf63c9bdb380501", "class_name": "RelatedNodeInfo"}, "3": {"node_id": "6341faa8-e7eb-4808-88aa-7a304abd0103", "node_type": "1", "metadata": {"Header_1": "What is Wollastonite?", "Header_2": " How Wollastonite Provides Plants with Ca and Si", "Header_3": "Silicon"}, "hash": "38ba0fb8f7af955ff1680bec68d2642da1aa1836a4bda877be54d34167d208f4", "class_name": "RelatedNodeInfo"}}, "text": "Calcium
- Calcium bicarbonate  (Ca(HCO₃)₂) is unstable and fairly easily decomposes to Limestone (CaCO₃):
		- Ca(HCO₃)₂ (Calcium bicarbonate)→CaCO₃ (Limestone)+  CO₂ (carbon Dioxide) + H₂O (Water)

- Soils with a pH below 7 (acidic soils) contain hydrogen ions (H+). These hydrogen ions react with the Limestone (CaCO3) to form Calcium ions (Ca2+), Water (H2O), and Carbon Dioxide (CO2).
	- CaCO3 (Limestone) + 2H+ (hydrogen ions) → Ca2+ (Calcium ions) + H2O (Water) + CO2 (carbon Dioxide)", "mimetype": "text/plain", "start_char_idx": 1837, "end_char_idx": 2326, "text_template": "{metadata_str}

{content}", "metadata_template": "{key}: {value}", "metadata_seperator": "
", "class_name": "TextNode"}

Header_2: How Wollastonite Provides Plants with Ca and Si
